elements.content: The title trifunctional ligand has been prepared, and coordination chemistry with La(III), Pr(III), and Yb(III) has been examined to assess the ligand's chelation properties. In 1:1 complexes, the ligand binds in a bidentate mode to the Ln(III) ions through the pyridyl N-oxide group and unexpectedly with the “long-arm” phosphine oxide group. The “short-arm” phosphine oxide group points away from the primary chelate ring and forms a monodentate bridge bond to the Ln(III) ion in a second Ln(L)(NO3)3 unit.
elements.clean_text: The title trifunctional ligand has been prepared, and coordination chemistry with La(III), Pr(III), and Yb(III) has been examined to assess the ligand's chelation properties. In 1:1 complexes, the ligand binds in a bidentate mode to the Ln(III) ions through the pyridyl N-oxide group and unexpectedly with the "long-arm" phosphine oxide group. The "short-arm" phosphine oxide group points away from the primary chelate ring and forms a monodentate bridge bond to the Ln(III) ion in a second Ln(L)(NO3)3 unit.

elements.content: The neutral bifunctional ligands (carbamoylmethyl)phosphonates (CMPs) and (carbamoylmethyl)phosphine oxides (CMPOs) coordinate effectively to trivalent and tetravalent f-block element cations even when in competition with high concentrations of mineral acids. This property makes these ligands practical as analytical and process scale liquid−liquid extraction (LLE) reagents in nuclear materials separations. This includes the development of the commercially useful TRUEX process. Until recently, only CMP and CMPO ligands were known to display increased distribution ratios, K D = [M]org/[M]aq, with increasing HCl or HNO3 concentration above 1 M. Our group has been attempting to design and synthesize additional ligand classes with this performance capability. Using known and evolving fundamental coordination principles for f-block element cations, we have developed a new family of chelates that include phosphinopyridine N,P-dioxides (NOPOs), (phosphinomethyl)pyridine N,P-dioxides (MNOPOs), and bis(phosphinomethyl)-pyridine N,P,P‘-trioxides (DMNOPOPOs). On the basis of coordination principles deduced for d-block metal ions, it would be expected that NOPO ligands would produce more stable complexes with M(III) and M(IV) ions since this ligand would provide six-membered chelate ring structures. In fact, it appears that MNOPO complexes that display seven-membered chelate rings have superior stability compared to NOPO complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The neutral bifunctional ligands (carbamoylmethyl)phosphonates (CMPs) and (carbamoylmethyl)phosphine oxides (CMPOs) coordinate effectively to trivalent and tetravalent f-block element cations even when in competition with high concentrations of mineral acids. This property makes these ligands practical as analytical and process scale liquid-liquid extraction (LLE) reagents in nuclear materials separations. This includes the development of the commercially useful TRUEX process. Until recently, only CMP and CMPO ligands were known to display increased distribution ratios, K D = [M]org/[M]aq, with increasing HCl or HNO3 concentration above 1 M. Our group has been attempting to design and synthesize additional ligand classes with this performance capability. Using known and evolving fundamental coordination principles for f-block element cations, we have developed a new family of chelates that include phosphinopyridine N,P-dioxides (NOPOs), (phosphinomethyl)pyridine N,P-dioxides (MNOPOs), and bis(phosphinomethyl)-pyridine N,P,P‘-trioxides (DMNOPOPOs). On the basis of coordination principles deduced for d-block metal ions, it would be expected that NOPO ligands would produce more stable complexes with M(III) and M(IV) ions since this ligand would provide six-membered chelate ring structures. In fact, it appears that MNOPO complexes that display seven-membered chelate rings have superior stability compared to NOPO complexes.

elements.content:
<fig id="ic0109041f1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label></label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="ic0109041f1.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

The success of an LLE process depends on more than just the strength of the interaction between the metal ion and organic ligand. For example, it has also been observed that the extraction of Eu(III) and Am(III) in HNO3 solutions is enhanced, at high acid concentrations, by addition of tributyl phosphate (TBP) to CMP or CMPO in an aliphatic diluent. It has been suggested that the TBP acts not as a ligand but as an organic-phase modifier by enhancing the effective polarity of the organic-phase diluent. The parallel observations with NOPO and MNOPO have not yet been made since aliphatic-soluble derivatives have only recently been prepared and extraction measurements have not yet been started. Nonetheless, successful use of TBP as a phase modifier in the CMPO/TRUEX LLE system suggests that it would be interesting to attempt to combine chelate ligation and phase modification properties in a single reagent.
elements.clean_text: The success of an LLE process depends on more than just the strength of the interaction between the metal ion and organic ligand. For example, it has also been observed that the extraction of Eu(III) and Am(III) in HNO3 solutions is enhanced, at high acid concentrations, by addition of tributyl phosphate (TBP) to CMP or CMPO in an aliphatic diluent. It has been suggested that the TBP acts not as a ligand but as an organic-phase modifier by enhancing the effective polarity of the organic-phase diluent. The parallel observations with NOPO and MNOPO have not yet been  made since aliphatic-soluble derivatives have only recently been prepared and extraction measurements have not yet been started. Nonetheless, successful use of TBP as a phase modifier in the CMPO/TRUEX LLE system suggests that it would be interesting to attempt to combine chelate ligation and phase modification properties in a single reagent.

elements.content: In this paper, we report the formation and chelation behavior of an interesting new derivative in the MNOPO family, 1-(diphenylphosphine oxide)-1-(2‘-pyridyl N-oxide)-3-(diphenylphosphine oxide)propane (1). Subsequent questions that should be addressed include the following:  (a) Will this ligand form stable seven-membered chelate complexes with lanthanide(III) (Ln(III)) ions? (b) Can the pendant diphenylphosphine oxide arm serve as an intramolecular phase modifier in an LLE process? The first question is addressed in this paper, and the second will be the subject of future LLE studies.
elements.clean_text: In this paper, we report the formation and chelation behavior of an interesting new derivative in the MNOPO family, 1-(diphenylphosphine oxide)-1-(2‘-pyridyl N-oxide)-3-(diphenylphosphine oxide)propane (1). Subsequent questions that should be addressed include the following: (a) Will this ligand form stable seven-membered chelate complexes with lanthanide(III) (Ln(III)) ions? (b) Can the pendant diphenylphosphine oxide arm serve as an intramolecular phase modifier in an LLE process? The first question is addressed in this paper, and the second will be the subject of future LLE studies.

General Information . The organic reagents used in the syntheses were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. Organic solvents were purchased from VWR and either used as received or dried by standard procedures as required. The lanthanide nitrate salts were purchased from Ventron. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Mattson 2020 FTIR spectrometer (4 cm-1 resolution), and NMR spectra were obtained on Bruker FX-250 and JEOL GSX-400 NMR spectrometers with chemical shift standards:  1H, 13C (Me4Si), 31P (85% H3PO4). All downfield shifts from the reference were designated as +δ. Mass spectra were obtained at the Midwest Center for Mass Spectrometry, University of Nebraska. Elemental analyses were acquired from Galbraith Laboratories.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 General Information . The organic reagents used in the syntheses were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. Organic solvents were purchased from VWR and either used as received or dried by standard procedures as required. The lanthanide nitrate salts were purchased from Ventron. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Mattson 2020 FTIR spectrometer (4 cm-1 resolution), and NMR spectra were obtained on Bruker FX-250 and JEOL GSX-400 NMR spectrometers with chemical shift standards: 1H, 13C (Me4Si), 31P (85% H3PO4). All downfield shifts from the reference were designated as +δ. Mass spectra were obtained at the Midwest Center for Mass Spectrometry, University of Nebraska. Elemental analyses were acquired from Galbraith Laboratories.

elements.content: Ligand Synthesis . A sample of 2-[(diphenylphosphino)methyl)]pyridine10 (1.00 g, 3.41 mmol) and diphenylvinylphosphine oxide (0.817 g, 3.58 mmol) were combined in dry tetrahydrofuran (THF, 30 mL) under dry nitrogen. The contents of the flask were cooled in an ice bath (15 min), and BuLi (0.5 mL, 0.92 M in hexane) solution was added dropwise from an airtight syringe. The mixture was stirred at ice temperature (3 h) and then overnight at room temperature. The solvent was removed with a rotary evaporator and the residue dissolved in iPrOH (15 mL). A white solid was recovered after addition of aqueous HCl solution (30 mL, 2 M). The subsequent workup can be accomplished in air. The mixture was chilled and filtered and the solid rinsed with pentane. The solid was then slurried with CHCl3 (50 mL) and aqueous Na2CO3 solution (25 mL, 0.25 M) and transferred to a separatory funnel. After mixing, the aqueous phase was removed and the organic phase contacted with additional Na2CO3 solution (25 mL, 0.25 M). The resulting combined chloroform phases were evaporated, leaving a white solid (2). Yield:  0.63 g (35%). Mp:  189−193 °C. Anal. Calcd for C32H29N4O2P2:  C, 73.70; H, 5.60; N, 2.69. Found:  C, 73.21; H, 5.64; N, 2.55. IR (KBr, cm-1):  1190 (νPO), 1175 (νPO). FAB-MS:  m/e (fragment) 522 (M + 1+), 201 (Ph2P(O)+). NMR (23 °C):  31P{1H} (CDCl3) δ 32.7; 1H (CDCl3) δ 2.10−2.57 (m, H2,3, 4H), 4.05 (m, H1, 1H), 7.00 (m, H5 ‘, 1H), 7.17−7.56 (m, phenyl, 20H), 7.75−7.83 (m, 2H), 8.37 (m, H6 ‘, 1H); 13C{1H} δ 21.7 (C2), 27.5 (dd, C3, 1 J PC = 71.0 Hz, 3 J PC = 12.0 Hz), 49.5 (dd, C1, 1 J PC = 64.8 Hz, 3 J PC = 11.9 Hz), 122.0 (C5 ‘), 124.3 (C3 ‘), 136.4 (C4 ‘), 149.0 (C6 ‘), 155.9 (C2 ‘), 127.9−133.8 (phenyl).

NMR (23 °C): 31P{1H} (CDCl3) δ 32.7; 1H (CDCl3) δ 2.10-2.57 (m, H2,3, 4H), 4.05 (m, H1, 1H), 7.00 (m, H5 ‘, 1H), 7.17-7.56 (m, phenyl, 20H), 7.75-7.83 (m, 2H), 8.37 (m, H6 ‘, 1H); 13C{1H} δ 21.7 (C2), 27.5 (dd, C3, 1 J PC = 71.0 Hz, 3 J PC = 12.0 Hz), 49.5 (dd, C1, 1 J PC = 64.8 Hz, 3 J PC = 11.9 Hz), 122.0 (C5 ‘), 124.3 (C3 ‘), 136.4 (C4 ‘), 149.0 (C6 ‘), 155.9 (C2 ‘), 127.9-133.8 (phenyl).

elements.content: A sample of 2 (2.048 g, 3.93 mmol) dissolved in glacial acetic acid (10 mL) was combined with hydrogen peroxide (2 mL, 30%, 17.6 mmol), and the solution was stirred in a closed flask (23 °C). After 2 days an additional portion (2 mL) of H2O2 was added and stirred (1 day). The resulting mixture was evaporated, the solid treated with water (10 mL), and the resulting mixture evaporated. The resulting yellow residue was treated with CHCl3 (30 mL) and extracted with saturated aqueous Na2CO3 (2 × 25 mL). The separated aqueous phase was then extracted with fresh CHCl3 (10 mL), and the CHCl3 phases were combined and treated with distilled water (25 mL). The separated water phase was extracted with CHCl3, and all of the CHCl3 phases were combined. This cycling is required since the CHCl3 solution of 1 has a small solubility in water. The CHCl3 phase was evaporated to dryness and recrystallized from CHCl3/pentane as a white solid (1). Yield:  1.89 g (89.5%). Mp:  214−216 °C. Anal. Calcd for C32H29NO3P2:  C, 71.50; H, 5.44; N, 2.61. Found:  C, 70.42 H, 5.67 N, 2.47. IR (KBr, cm-1):  1231 (νNO), 1198 (νPO), 1181 (νPO). FAB-MS:  m/e (fragment):  538 (M + 1+). HRMS calcd for 12C32H30 14N16O3 31P2 538.1701, found 538.1713. NMR (23 °C):  31P{1H} (CDCl3) δ 36.7, 36.8; 1H (CD3OD) δ 2.04−2.43 (m, H2,3, 4H), 5.32 (m, H1, 1H), 7.19−7.81 (aromatic, 24H), 8.08 (d, J = 6.4 Hz, H6 ‘, 1H); 13C{1H} (CDCl3) δ 22.8 (C2), 28.0 (dd, C3, 1 J PC = 71.0 Hz, 3 J PC = 11.9 Hz), 39.1 (dd, C1, 1 J PC = 66.7 Hz, 3 J PC = 13.8 Hz), 126.6 (C5 ‘), 127.9 (C3 ‘), 140.7 (C6 ‘), 148.4 (C2 ‘), 129.6−133.9 (C4 ‘, phenyl). Compound 1 is soluble in CHCl3 and slightly soluble in water, 0.1 M HNO3, and benzene.

NMR (23 °C): 31P{1H} (CDCl3) δ 36.7, 36.8; 1H (CD3OD) δ 2.04-2.43 (m, H2,3, 4H), 5.32 (m, H1, 1H), 7.19-7.81 (aromatic, 24H), 8.08 (d, J = 6.4 Hz, H6 ‘, 1H); 13C{1H} (CDCl3) δ 22.8 (C2), 28.0 (dd, C3, 1 J PC = 71.0 Hz, 3 J PC = 11.9 Hz), 39.1 (dd, C1, 1 J PC = 66.7 Hz, 3 J PC = 13.8 Hz), 126.6 (C5 ‘), 127.9 (C3 ‘), 140.7 (C6 ‘), 148.4 (C2 ‘), 129.6-133.9 (C4 ‘, phenyl). elements.content: Preparation of the Complexes . Solutions of lanthanide salts (0.5 mmol in 10 mL of EtOH) and 1 (0.5 mmol in 5 mL of CHCl3) were combined and stirred (2 h). Precipitates formed immediately. These were recovered by filtration and washed with pentane. The solid samples were vacuum-dried prior to analysis. The infrared spectrum for each complex was recorded (KBr, cm-1):  Pr(1)(NO3)3, 1150 (νNO), 1125 (νPO), 1096 (νPO); Tb(1)(NO3)3, 1153 (νNO), 1125 (νPO) 1098 (νPO); Yb(1)(NO3)3, 1157 (νNO), 1125 (νPO), 1098 (νPO). The CHN analysis was completed only for the Pr(1)(NO3)3 complex. Anal. Calcd for Pr(1)(NO3)3·H2O, C32H31N4O13P2Pr:  C, 43.55; H, 3.54; N, 6.35. Found:  C, 43.32; H, 3.84; N, 6.01.
elements.clean_text: Preparation of the Complexes . Solutions of lanthanide salts (0.5 mmol in 10 mL of EtOH) and 1 (0.5 mmol in 5 mL of CHCl3) were combined and stirred (2 h). Precipitates formed immediately. These were recovered by filtration and washed with pentane. The solid samples were vacuum-dried prior to analysis. The infrared spectrum for each complex was recorded (KBr, cm-1): Pr(1)(NO3)3, 1150 (νNO), 1125 (νPO), 1096 (νPO); Tb(1)(NO3)3, 1153 (νNO), 1125 (νPO) 1098 (νPO); Yb(1)(NO3)3, 1157 (νNO), 1125 (νPO), 1098 (νPO). The CHN analysis was completed only for the Pr(1)(NO3)3 complex. Anal. Calcd for Pr(1)(NO3)3⋅H2O, C32H31N4O13P2Pr: C, 43.55; H, 3.54; N, 6.35. Found: C, 43.32; H, 3.84; N, 6.01.

elements.content: X-ray Diffraction Study . A small (0.10 × 0.08 × 0.06 mm) colorless prism-shaped crystal of Pr(1)(NO3)3 obtained by slow evaporation of a methanol solution of the complex was mounted in a glass capillary tube which was then sealed and placed in a cold stream (193 K) on a Siemens P4 X-ray diffractometer with a CCD area detector. Data collection was performed with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Selected crystal and refinement data are summarized in Table . Data were recorded in the hemisphere mode with a measurement rate of 10 s per frame. A small absorption correction was applied using SADABS. Data reduction and refinement were accomplished with SHELXL 97. The structure was solved by direct methods, and full-matrix least- squares refinements were employed. The refinements were well behaved except for that of the outer-sphere water molecule. The occupancy of the O(13) position was varied, and it converged to 0.73. Hence, it was set at 0.75 in the final model to achieve an integral number (6) of waters in the unit cell. The H atoms on O(13) were not located, and they were placed in idealized positions. All other H atoms were included (riding model) with U iso = 1.25U eq of the parent atom.
elements.clean_text: X-ray Diffraction Study . A small (0.10 × 0.08 × 0.06 mm) colorless prism-shaped crystal of Pr(1)(NO3)3 obtained by slow evaporation of a methanol solution of the complex was mounted in a glass capillary tube which was then sealed and placed in a cold stream (193 K) on a Siemens P4 X-ray diffractometer with a CCD area detector. Data collection was performed with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Selected crystal and refinement data are summarized in Table . Data were recorded in the hemisphere mode with a measurement rate of 10 s per frame. A small absorption correction was applied using SADABS. Data reduction and refinement were accomplished with SHELXL 97. The structure was solved by direct methods, and full-matrix least- squares refinements were employed. The refinements were well behaved except for that of the outer-sphere water molecule. The occupancy of the O(13) position was varied, and it converged to 0.73. Hence, it was set at 0.75 in the final model to achieve an integral number (6) of waters in the unit cell. The H atoms on O(13) were not located, and they were placed in idealized positions. All other H atoms were included (riding model) with U iso = 1.25U eq of the parent atom.

elements.content:
Crystallographic Data for Pr(1)(NO3)3·0.75H2O

empirical formula C32H30.5N4O12.75P2Pr V, Å3 7468.8(11) fw 877.95 space group Pbca a, Å 20.991(2) Z 8 b, Å 16.397(1) D calcd, g/cm3 1.562 c, Å 21.700(2) μ, mm-1 1.457 α, deg 90 R1, a  wR2 b   0.0489, 0.1125 β, deg 90 (I > 2σ(I)) γ, deg 90

a  R1 = ∑||F o| − |F c||/∑|F o|. b  wR2 = [∑[w(F o 2 − Fc 2)2]/∑[w(F o 2)2]1/2.

The target ligand 1 was obtained in about 30% overall yield from the unoptimized reaction sequence outlined in Scheme . The first step in the synthesis produces the precursor 1-(diphenylphosphine oxide)-1-(2‘-pyridyl)-3-(diphenylphosphine oxide)propane (2) in about 35% yield from the Michael addition of the reactive methylene group in 2-[(diphenylphosphino)methyl]pyridine (3) to the activated vinyl group in diphenylvinylphosphine oxide (4). The reaction is catalyzed with the strong base BuLi in THF solution. The formation of 2 is indicated by its 31P{1H} NMR resonance at δ 32.7. No other reaction products are formed, and reaction mixtures monitored by 31P{1H} NMR spectroscopy show only the resonance for 2 along with resonances for the starting materials 3 (31P{1H} δ 30) and 4 (31P{1H} δ 24). The precursor is a white solid that was characterized by CHN analysis, FAB-MS, and IR and 1H, 13C, and 31P NMR spectroscopy. The IR spectrum shows two absorptions at 1190 and 1175 cm-1 that are tentatively assigned on the basis of literature precedence to νPO for the two Ph2P(O) fragments. FAB-MS shows an intense ion for the M + 1+ species (m/e 522) that is characteristic of MNPOPO ligands. The 31P{1H} NMR spectrum unexpectedly shows only one resonance, δ 32.7. This requires that the inequivalent Ph2P(O) groups must be accidentally magnetically equivalent. The 1H and 13C{1H} NMR spectra have been assigned, and they are consistent with the proposed structure.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The target ligand 1 was obtained in about 30% overall yield from the unoptimized reaction sequence outlined in Scheme . The first step in the synthesis produces the precursor 1-(diphenylphosphine oxide)-1-(2‘-pyridyl)-3-(diphenylphosphine oxide)propane (2) in about 35% yield from the Michael addition of the reactive methylene group in 2-[(diphenylphosphino)methyl]pyridine (3) to the activated vinyl group in diphenylvinylphosphine oxide (4). The reaction is catalyzed with the strong base BuLi in THF solution. The formation of 2 is indicated by its 31P{1H} NMR resonance at δ 32.7. No other reaction products are formed, and reaction mixtures monitored by 31P{1H} NMR spectroscopy show only the resonance for 2 along with resonances for the starting materials 3 (31P{1H} δ 30) and 4 (31P{1H} δ 24). The precursor is a white solid that was characterized by CHN analysis, FAB-MS, and IR and 1H, 13C, and 31P NMR spectroscopy. The IR spectrum shows two absorptions at 1190 and 1175 cm-1 that are tentatively assigned on the basis of literature precedence to νPO for the two Ph2P(O) fragments. FAB-MS shows an intense ion for the M + 1+ species (m/e 522) that is characteristic of MNPOPO ligands. The 31P{1H} NMR spectrum unexpectedly shows only one resonance, δ 32.7. This requires that the inequivalent Ph2P(O) groups must be accidentally magnetically equivalent. The 1H and 13C{1H} NMR spectra have been assigned, and they are consistent with the proposed structure.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="ic0109041h00001" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="ic0109041h00001.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

The second step of the ligand synthesis involves the oxidation of the pyridine fragment with a hydrogen peroxide/glacial acetic acid mixture at 23 °C for 2 days. The reaction is accelerated by use of higher reaction temperatures, but some decomposition also takes place. Compound 1 is isolated as a white solid that provides adequate CHN analytical data. The compound displays three strong absorptions in the IR spectrum, 1231, 1198, and 1181 cm-1, that are tentatively assigned to νNO,νPO, and νPO stretching frequencies, respectively. The high-resolution FAB-MS shows an M + 1+ parent ion at 538.1713 (calcd 538.1701). In this case, the 31P{1H} NMR spectrum displays two closely spaced (δ 36.7, 36.8), equal-intensity resonances. The 1H and 13C{1H} NMR spectra are closely comparable to the spectra for 2.
elements.clean_text: The second step of the ligand synthesis involves the oxidation of the pyridine fragment with a hydrogen peroxide/glacial acetic acid mixture at 23 °C for 2 days. The reaction is accelerated by use of higher reaction temperatures, but some decomposition also takes place. Compound 1 is isolated as a white solid that provides adequate CHN analytical data. The compound displays three strong absorptions in the IR spectrum, 1231, 1198, and 1181 cm-1, that are tentatively assigned to νNO,νPO, and νPO stretching frequencies, respectively. The high-resolution FAB-MS shows an M + 1+ parent ion at 538.1713 (calcd 538.1701). In this case, the 31P{1H} NMR spectrum displays two closely spaced (δ 36.7, 36.8), equal-intensity resonances. The 1H and 13C{1H} NMR spectra are closely comparable to the spectra for 2.

elements.content: As indicated in the Introduction, the primary interest in compound 1 revolves around its potential tridentate ligation properties and/or its potential to act as a phase modifier in two-phase extractions. As a result, the coordination chemistry of 1 with Pr(NO3)3, Tb(NO3)3, and Yb(NO3)3 was explored. When combined in a 1:1 L:M ratio, solid complexes are isolated as crystalline solids. The infrared spectra of the complexes are identical and show bands at 1157−1150 cm-1 that can be assigned to νNO and 1125 and 1096 cm-1 that are assigned to νPO. Each band is shifted to a lower frequency compared to the corresponding absorption in the free ligand:  ΔνNO = 74−81 cm-1, ΔνPO = 73−85 cm-1. These data suggest that all three functional groups of 1 are involved in the lanthanide coordination; however, they provide no evidence related to ligand denticity. Therefore, the molecular structure of one of the complexes, Pr(1)(NO3)3, was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction techniques.

As a result, the coordination chemistry of 1 with Pr(NO3)3, Tb(NO3)3, and Yb(NO3)3 was explored. When combined in a 1:1 L:M ratio, solid complexes are isolated as crystalline solids. The infrared spectra of the complexes are identical and show bands at 1157-1150 cm-1 that can be assigned to νNO and 1125 and 1096 cm-1 that are assigned to νPO. Each band is shifted to a lower frequency compared to the corresponding absorption in the free ligand: ΔνNO = 74-81 cm-1, ΔνPO = 73-85 cm-1. These data suggest that all three functional groups of 1 are involved in the lanthanide coordination; however, they provide no evidence related to ligand denticity. Therefore, the molecular structure of one of the complexes, Pr(1)(NO3)3, was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction techniques.

elements.content: The compound crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pbca. A view of the molecule is shown in Figure , and selected bond lengths are listed in Table . The parent MNOPO ligand (R = Ph) has been shown to coordinate with Ln(III) ions in a bidentate mode through the pyr NO group and the PO group terminating the exo −CH2(Ph)2PO arm. In fact, with sufficient MNOPO available, 4:1 L/M complexes form in which the bidentate ligand oxygen atoms generate the entire inner coordination sphere (CN = 8) and the nitrate ions are displaced to the outer sphere. The new MNOPO derivative 1 presents, to an approaching Ln(III) ion, three potential donor sites:  the pyr NO, the short-arm −CH(Ph)2PO, and the long-arm −C(H)(C2H4)(Ph)2PO oxygen atoms. On the basis of earlier studies, we expected that the resting free ligand would have a structure with the three O-donor dipoles rotated away from each other. In the presence of a strong field generated by a highly charged Ln(III) cation, we also expected that the short-arm phosphoryl group would reorient, forming, together with the pyr NO, a seven-membered bidentate chelate interaction. It was not clear if the long arm could also reorient its secondary structure in a manner that would produce a tridentate interaction. Therefore, it was not surprising to find that the structure adopted in the 1:1 1/Pr(III) complex crystal structure contains three bidentate nitrate anions and one bidentate chelating ligand, 1, in the inner coordination sphere. It was unexpected, however, to find that the long-arm −C(H)(C2H4)(Ph)2PO and the pyr NO donor groups are used, producing a nine-atom chelate ring. The short-arm −C(H)(Ph)2PO is not silent. This group, in each Pr(1)(NO3)3 unit, coordinates with the Pr(III) ion in a neighboring Pr(1)(NO3)3 unit. The result is a chain structure extending along the b axis as shown in Figure , with each Pr(III) having a coordination number of nine. The inner coordination sphere as shown in Figure approximates a distorted capped square antiprism. Although IR spectral data are not unambiguous since the νNO and νPO assignments are only tentative, the IR of the complex in CHCl3 was obtained to assess possible chelate structure changes in solution. The νNO and two νPO bands are found at the same frequencies as reported for the complex in KBr. This suggests that the bridged chain structure persists in CHCl3 solution.

The parent MNOPO ligand (R = Ph) has been shown to coordinate with  Ln(III) ions in a bidentate mode through the pyr NO group and the PO group terminating the exo -CH2(Ph)2PO arm. In fact, with sufficient MNOPO available, 4:1 L/M complexes form in which the bidentate ligand oxygen atoms generate the entire inner coordination sphere (CN = 8) and the nitrate ions are displaced to the outer sphere. The new MNOPO derivative 1 presents, to an approaching Ln(III) ion, three potential donor sites: the pyr NO, the short-arm -CH(Ph)2PO, and the long-arm -C(H)(C2H4)(Ph)2PO oxygen atoms. On the basis of earlier studies, we expected that the resting free ligand would have a structure with the three O-donor dipoles rotated away from each other. In the presence of a strong field generated by a highly charged Ln(III) cation, we also expected that the short-arm phosphoryl group would reorient, forming, together with the pyr NO, a seven-membered bidentate chelate interaction. It was not clear if the long arm could also reorient its secondary structure in a manner that would produce a tridentate interaction. Therefore, it was not surprising to find that the structure adopted in the 1:1 1/Pr(III) complex crystal structure contains three bidentate nitrate anions and one bidentate chelating ligand, 1, in the inner coordination sphere. It was unexpected, however, to find that the long-arm -C(H)(C2H4)(Ph)2PO and the pyr NO donor groups are used, producing a nine-atom chelate ring. The short-arm -C(H)(Ph)2PO is not silent. This group, in each Pr(1)(NO3)3 unit, coordinates with the Pr(III) ion in a neighboring Pr(1)(NO3)3 unit. The result is a chain structure extending along the b axis as shown in Figure , with each Pr(III) having a coordination number of nine. The inner coordination sphere as shown in Figure  approximates a distorted capped square antiprism. Although IR spectral data are not unambiguous since the νNO and νPO assignments are only tentative, the IR of the complex in CHCl3 was obtained to assess possible chelate structure changes in solution. The νNO and two νPO bands are found at the same frequencies as reported for the complex in KBr. This suggests that the bridged chain structure persists in CHCl3 solution.

elements.content:
Selected Bond Lengths (Å) for Pr(1)(NO3)3·0.75H2O

Pr−O(1) 2.400(4) P(1)−O(1) 1.501(4) Pr−O(2) 2.370(4) P(2)−O(2) 1.506(4) Pr−O(3) 2.400(4) N(1)−O(3) 1.329(6) Pr−O(5) 2.582(4) N(2)−O(4) 1.219(7) Pr−O(6) 2.554(4) N(2)−O(5) 1.263(7) Pr−O(7) 2.559(5) N(2)−O(6) 1.278(7) Pr−O(8) 2.580(5) N(3)−O(9) 1.234(7) Pr−O(10) 2.536(5) N(3)−O(7) 1.238(8) Pr−O(11) 2.540(4) N(3)−O(8) 1.247(8) Pr···N(2) 2.998(5) N(4)−O(12) 1.224(7) Pr···N(3) 2.999(5) N(4)−O(10) 1.257(7) Pr···N(4) 2.957(5) N(4)−O(11) 1.270(7)

The chain structure described here is reminiscent of the chain structure adopted by the trifunctional octahydroacridine N,P,P‘-trioxide ligand 5 with Ln(III) ions. Here one Ph2PO group reorients its PO dipole so that a bidentate pyr NO/Ph2PO seven-membered chelate interaction with Ln(III) occurs. The second Ph2PO group in the threo isomer obtained cannot approach the same Ln(III) ion. Instead, this Ph2PO group bridges to a second Ln(5)(NO3)3 complex unit, and a chain structure results.
elements.clean_text: The chain structure described here is reminiscent of the chain structure adopted by the trifunctional octahydroacridine N,P,P‘-trioxide ligand 5 with Ln(III) ions. Here one Ph2PO group reorients its PO dipole so that a bidentate pyr NO/Ph2PO seven-membered chelate interaction with Ln(III) occurs. The second Ph2PO group in the threo isomer obtained cannot approach the same Ln(III) ion. Instead, this Ph2PO group bridges to a second Ln(5)(NO3)3 complex unit, and a chain structure results.

elements.content:
<fig id="ic0109041f3" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label></label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="ic0109041f3.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

The long-arm Ph2P(O)−Pr bond length in the Pr(1)(NO3)3 unit is 2.370(4) Å, and this is shorter than the bridging short-arm Ph2P(O)−Pr bond length, 2.400(4) Å, and the pyr N(O)−Pr bond length, 2.400(4) Å. These distances can be compared with bond lengths in Nd(5)(NO3)3:  Ph2P(O)−Nd = 2.324(13) Å, bridging Ph2P(O)−Nd = 2.330(8) Å, and pyr N(O)−Nd = 2.424(10) Å. The difference in ionic radii, Pr(III) (CN = 8) 1.14 Å, Nd(III) (CN = 8) 1.12 Å, is partially responsible for the M−O bond length variations in these complexes; however, it does not explain all the variations. Clearly, both P(O)−Pr bond lengths are longer than comparable P(O)−Nd bond lengths, which suggests that the phosphoryl/metal interactions are not as strong in Pr(1)(NO3)3. In contrast, the N(O)−Pr bond length is slightly shorter. That said, the P(O)−Pr and N(O)−Pr bond lengths in Pr(1)(NO3)3 are both shorter than the average separations in the 2:1 complex (MNOPO)2Pr(NO3)3 (R = Ph) (CN = 10):  P(O)−Pr = 2.456(6) Å and N(O)−Pr = 2.445(7) Å. This may reflect both an increased Pr(III) coordination number and potentially greater ligand packing repulsions in the latter complex.
elements.clean_text: The long-arm Ph2P(O)-Pr bond length in the Pr(1)(NO3)3 unit is 2.370(4) Å, and this is shorter than the bridging short-arm Ph2P(O)-Pr bond length, 2.400(4) Å, and the pyr N(O)-Pr bond length, 2.400(4) Å. These distances can be compared with bond lengths in Nd(5)(NO3)3: Ph2P(O)-Nd = 2.324(13) Å, bridging Ph2P(O)-Nd = 2.330(8) Å, and  pyr N(O)-Nd = 2.424(10) Å. The difference in ionic radii, Pr(III) (CN = 8) 1.14 Å, Nd(III) (CN = 8) 1.12 Å, is partially responsible for the M-O bond length variations in these complexes; however, it does not explain all the variations. Clearly, both P(O)-Pr bond lengths are longer than comparable P(O)-Nd bond lengths, which suggests that the phosphoryl/metal interactions are not as strong in Pr(1)(NO3)3. In contrast, the N(O)-Pr bond length is slightly shorter. That said, the P(O)-Pr and N(O)-Pr bond lengths in Pr(1)(NO3)3 are both shorter than the average separations in the 2:1 complex (MNOPO)2Pr(NO3)3 (R = Ph) (CN = 10): P(O)-Pr = 2.456(6) Å and N(O)-Pr = 2.445(7) Å. This may reflect both an increased Pr(III) coordination number and potentially greater ligand packing repulsions in the latter complex.

elements.content: Some points related to the secondary structure of Pr(1)(NO3)3 are worth mention. First, six water molecules appear in the unit cell. The occupancy of the O(13) atom position was varied from 0.5 to 0.75 and found to converge best with a model having 0.75 occupancy. H-atoms on the water molecules were not resolved; therefore, they were placed in idealized positions to link the closest nonbonded O···O contacts:  O(4)···O(13)···O(9). The result is a two-dimensional corrugated net in the x − y[a − b] plane that is not connected in the z[c] direction. It is also apparent that there are numerous nonbonded interactions involving the phenyl groups; however, these C−H···O interactions will be much weaker, and they should play a diminished role in the crystal chemistry.
elements.clean_text: Some points related to the secondary structure of Pr(1)(NO3)3 are worth mention. First, six water molecules appear in the unit cell. The occupancy of the O(13) atom position was varied from 0.5 to 0.75 and found to converge best with a model having 0.75 occupancy. H-atoms on the water molecules were not resolved; therefore, they were placed in idealized positions to link the closest nonbonded O⋅⋅⋅O contacts: O(4)⋅⋅⋅O(13)⋅⋅⋅O(9). The result is a two-dimensional corrugated net in the x - y[a - b] plane that is not connected in the z[c] direction. It is also apparent that there are numerous nonbonded interactions involving the phenyl groups; however, these C-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions will be much weaker, and they should play a diminished role in the crystal chemistry.

elements.content: The ligand chelate structure is certainly unexpected; however, given the features found in the secondary structure, especially nonbonded phenyl group interactions, it may be that 1 simply cannot orient properly to produce a seven-membered chelate ring using pyr NO and short-arm −C(H)(Ph)2PO donor groups. Studies of the extraction behavior of 1 and its derivatives are planned, and the impact of the structural preference of 1 on extraction performance will be tested.
elements.clean_text: The ligand chelate structure is certainly unexpected; however, given the features found in the secondary structure, especially nonbonded phenyl group interactions, it may be that 1 simply cannot orient properly to produce a seven-membered chelate ring using pyr NO and short-arm -C(H)(Ph)2PO donor groups. Studies of the extraction behavior of 1 and its derivatives are planned, and the impact of the structural preference of 1 on extraction performance will be tested.

cln_elements.content:
Ligand Synthesis . A sample of 2-[(diphenylphosphino)methyl)]pyridine10 (1.00 g, 3.41 mmol) and diphenylvinylphosphine oxide (0.817 g, 3.58 mmol) were combined in dry tetrahydrofuran (THF, 30 mL) under dry nitrogen. The contents of the flask were cooled in an ice bath (15 min), and BuLi (0.5 mL, 0.92 M in hexane) solution was added dropwise from an airtight syringe. The mixture was stirred at ice temperature (3 h) and then overnight at room temperature. The solvent was removed with a rotary evaporator and the residue dissolved in iPrOH (15 mL). A white solid was recovered after addition of aqueous HCl solution (30 mL, 2 M). The subsequent workup can be accomplished in air. The mixture was chilled and filtered and the solid rinsed with pentane. The solid was then slurried with CHCl3 (50 mL) and aqueous Na2CO3 solution (25 mL, 0.25 M) and transferred to a separatory funnel. After mixing, the aqueous phase was removed and the organic phase contacted with additional Na2CO3 solution (25 mL, 0.25 M). The resulting combined chloroform phases were evaporated, leaving a white solid (2). Yield:  0.63 g (35%). Mp:  189−193 °C. Anal. Calcd for C32H29N4O2P2:  C, 73.70; H, 5.60; N, 2.69. Found:  C, 73.21; H, 5.64; N, 2.55. IR (KBr, cm-1):  1190 (νPO), 1175 (νPO). FAB-MS:  m/e (fragment) 522 (M + 1+), 201 (Ph2P(O)+). NMR (23 °C):  31P{1H} (CDCl3) δ 32.7; 1H (CDCl3) δ 2.10−2.57 (m, H2,3, 4H), 4.05 (m, H1, 1H), 7.00 (m, H5 ‘, 1H), 7.17−7.56 (m, phenyl, 20H), 7.75−7.83 (m, 2H), 8.37 (m, H6 ‘, 1H); 13C{1H} δ 21.7 (C2), 27.5 (dd, C3, 1 J PC = 71.0 Hz, 3 J PC = 12.0 Hz), 49.5 (dd, C1, 1 J PC = 64.8 Hz, 3 J PC = 11.9 Hz), 122.0 (C5 ‘), 124.3 (C3 ‘), 136.4 (C4 ‘), 149.0 (C6 ‘), 155.9 (C2 ‘), 127.9−133.8 (phenyl).

A sample of 2 (2.048 g, 3.93 mmol) dissolved in glacial acetic acid (10 mL) was combined with hydrogen peroxide (2 mL, 30%, 17.6 mmol), and the solution was stirred in a closed flask (23 °C). After 2 days an additional portion (2 mL) of H2O2 was added and stirred (1 day). The resulting mixture was evaporated, the solid treated with water (10 mL), and the resulting mixture evaporated. The resulting yellow residue was treated with CHCl3 (30 mL) and extracted with saturated aqueous Na2CO3 (2 × 25 mL). The separated aqueous phase was then extracted with fresh CHCl3 (10 mL), and the CHCl3 phases were combined and treated with distilled water (25 mL). The separated water phase was extracted with CHCl3, and all of the CHCl3 phases were combined. This cycling is required since the CHCl3 solution of 1 has a small solubility in water. The CHCl3 phase was evaporated to dryness and recrystallized from CHCl3/pentane as a white solid (1). Yield:  1.89 g (89.5%). Mp:  214−216 °C. Anal. Calcd for C32H29NO3P2:  C, 71.50; H, 5.44; N, 2.61. Found:  C, 70.42 H, 5.67 N, 2.47. IR (KBr, cm-1):  1231 (νNO), 1198 (νPO), 1181 (νPO). FAB-MS:  m/e (fragment):  538 (M + 1+). HRMS calcd for 12C32H30 14N16O3 31P2 538.1701, found 538.1713. NMR (23 °C):  31P{1H} (CDCl3) δ 36.7, 36.8; 1H (CD3OD) δ 2.04−2.43 (m, H2,3, 4H), 5.32 (m, H1, 1H), 7.19−7.81 (aromatic, 24H), 8.08 (d, J = 6.4 Hz, H6 ‘, 1H); 13C{1H} (CDCl3) δ 22.8 (C2), 28.0 (dd, C3, 1 J PC = 71.0 Hz, 3 J PC = 11.9 Hz), 39.1 (dd, C1, 1 J PC = 66.7 Hz, 3 J PC = 13.8 Hz), 126.6 (C5 ‘), 127.9 (C3 ‘), 140.7 (C6 ‘), 148.4 (C2 ‘), 129.6−133.9 (C4 ‘, phenyl). Compound 1 is soluble in CHCl3 and slightly soluble in water, 0.1 M HNO3, and benzene.

Preparation of the Complexes . Solutions of lanthanide salts (0.5 mmol in 10 mL of EtOH) and 1 (0.5 mmol in 5 mL of CHCl3) were combined and stirred (2 h). Precipitates formed immediately. These were recovered by filtration and washed with pentane. The solid samples were vacuum-dried prior to analysis. The infrared spectrum for each complex was recorded (KBr, cm-1):  Pr(1)(NO3)3, 1150 (νNO), 1125 (νPO), 1096 (νPO); Tb(1)(NO3)3, 1153 (νNO), 1125 (νPO) 1098 (νPO); Yb(1)(NO3)3, 1157 (νNO), 1125 (νPO), 1098 (νPO). The CHN analysis was completed only for the Pr(1)(NO3)3 complex. Anal. Calcd for Pr(1)(NO3)3·H2O, C32H31N4O13P2Pr:  C, 43.55; H, 3.54; N, 6.35. Found:  C, 43.32; H, 3.84; N, 6.01.

a  R1 = ∑||F o| − |F c||/∑|F o|. b  wR2 = [∑[w(F o 2 − Fc 2)2]/∑[w(F o 2)2]1/2.
